name: irrigation, drip | irrigation | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20830/documentation

This dataset represents the drip irrigation in South Africa with a 90% irrigation efficieny. The inventory includes the water pumping of ground water and surface water, as well as the infrastructure. The water supplied to the plants (1m3) and the water evaporated or infiltrated shall be included in the crop production datasets.

This dataset starts with pumping water from wells and water bodies.

This dataset ends with delivering water to the plant and includes the water pumping, energy use, infrastructure, but not the water emissions of irrigation (shall be included in the crop production dataset).
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/016:Support activities to agriculture and post-harvest crop activities/0161:Support activities for crop production

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The data was collected for the given time range.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset contains South Africa specific data and general, technology specific information.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In drip irrigation the water is provided to the plants drop by drop, with micro-sprinklers or by forming fog-like conditions. This method is sometimes called trickle irrigation and involves dripping water onto the soil at very low rates from a system of small diameter plastic pipes fitted with outlets called emitters or drippers. Water is applied close to plants so that only part of the soil in which the roots grow is wetted, unlike surface and sprinkler irrigation, which involves wetting the whole soil profile. With drip irrigation water, applications are more frequent (usually every 1-3 days) than with other methods and this provides a very favourable high moisture level in the soil in which plants can flourish.;Drip irrigation is mainly applied in intensive cultivations planted in rows (vegetables, fruit trees, melons, bananas, papayas, flowers, grapes, etc.). It is not recommended for potatoes, salad leafy vegetables, groundnuts, alfalfa and other dense planted crops, although it can be applied successfully (FAO, 2007).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The material input are based on the FAO example drip irrigation design for watermelons (FAO, 2007). The data on water sources, irrigation efficiency and energy demand is compiled based on different data sources, incluiding the Global Map of Irrigation Areas (GMIA), FAO-AQUASTAT libary, national census reports and other internacional organizations or statistical services.

flow.name: irrigation
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/016:Support activities to agriculture and post-harvest crop activities/0161:Support activities for crop production

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values. The material input are based on the FAO example drip irrigation design for watermelons (FAO, 2007). The weight per m3 of water is calculated based on the lifespan of the equipment and the amount of water irrigated per ha and year. The lifespan for the distribution network is assumed to be ten years and the head control unit 20 years. An irrigation interval of 2 days is assumed. The irrigation system is assumed to be functional during a third of the year (irrigation interval between irrigation of 2days) and the water amount irrigated is 39.4 m3 per day (FAO, 2007). FAO. (2007). Handbook of pressurized irrigation techniques. Rome, Italy

exchanges.description: calculated value. The energy required to lift water for irrigation is a function of the lift or total head (Ht), the efficiencies of pumps used for extraction (e1), the driving efficiency (e2) and flow rates (FAO, 2007).

flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values. The material input are based on the FAO example drip irrigation design for watermelons (FAO, 2007). The weight per m3 of water is calculated based on the lifespan of the equipment and the amount of water irrigated per ha and year. The lifespan for the distribution network is assumed to be one year and the head control unit 20 years. An irrigation interval of 2 days is assumed. The irrigation system is assumed to be functional during a third of the year (irrigation interval between irrigation of 2days) and the water amount irrigated is 39.4 m3 per day (FAO, 2007). FAO. (2007). Handbook of pressurized irrigation techniques. Rome, Italy

exchanges.description: Calculated value. A tractor is assumed to install the drip irrigation system, with an average diesel consumption of 3.78kg/ha (4 times*0.25ha*4.5l/ha*0.83 kg/l), based on ecoinvent (Nemecek & Kägi, 2007). The energy consumption of levelling the field is assumed to be included in the energy use for field preparation, included in the crop production dataset.
